sen.j: 能瀬 資国（のせ すけくに、生没年不詳）は、平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期の武士・官人。
sen.e: Sukekuni NOSE (years of birth and death unknown) is a samurai and government official (lower or middle ranked) over the end of the Heian Era and the early period of the Kamakura Era.
Sukekuni NOSE (year of birth and death unknown) is a samurai and government official (lower or middle ranked) over the end of the Heian era and the early period of the Kamakura era.
sen.cmt: yearに訂正しました。era小文字にしました。
sen.e: Sukekuni NOSE (year of birth and death unknown) is a samurai and government official (lower or middle ranked) over the end of the Heian era and the early period of the Kamakura era.
He is the eldest son of Takayori NOSE.
He is the eldest son of Takayori NOSE.
He is the eldest son of Takayori NOSE.
Nakasuke is his younger brother.
Nakasuke is his younger brother.
Nakasuke is his younger brother.

sen.j: 信国、正国（政国）、倉垣資氏、国宗、信資、平信範室？、高階光兼室などの父。
sen.e: He is the father of Nobukuni, Masakuni, Sukeuji KURAGAKI, Kunimune, Nobusuke, the wife of TAIRA no Nobunori and the wife of Mitsukane TAKASHINA.
sen.cmt: 平信範室のあと、和文にはクエスチョンマークがありましたが、英文では省略しました。
sen.e: He is the father of Nobukuni, Masakuni, Sukeuji KURAGAKI, Kunimune, Nobusuke, the wife of TAIRA no Nobunori and the wife of Mitsukane TAKASHINA.
He is the father of Nobukuni, Masakuni, Sukeuji KURAGAKI, Kunimune, Nobusuke, the wife of TAIRA no Nobunori and the wife of Mitsukane TAKASHINA.
He called himself also Nose Kurodo (Chamberlain).
He called himself also Nose Kurodo (Chamberlain).
He called himself also Nose Kurodo (Chamberlain).

sen.j: 治承・寿永の乱の後に没落した多田源氏の一族であったが、父の開発した摂津国能勢郡の所領を継承しており、鎌倉期に入ってからも中央官人として蔵人や大学助、豊後国守などを務め正五位下に至った。
sen.e: He was from a family of the Tada-Genji (Minamoto clan), which was ruined after Jisho-Juei War, but he succeeded the territory in Nose-gun, Settsu Province, which his father had developed, served as a central government official (lower or middle ranked), such as Kurodo, Daigaku no suke (Assistant Director of the Bureau of Education) and Bungp no kuni no kami (Governor of Bungo Province), and reached Shogoinoge (Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) in the Kamakura period.

He was from a family of the Tada-Genji (Minamoto clan), which was ruined after Jisho-Juei War, but he succeeded the territory in Nose-gun, Settsu Province, which his father had developed, served as a central government official (lower or middle ranked), such as Kurodo, Daigaku no suke (Assistant Director of the Bureau of Education) and Bungp no kuni no kami (Governor of Bungo Province), and reached Shogoinoge (Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) in the Kamakura period.

He was from a family of the Tada-Genji (Minamoto clan), which was ruined after Jisho-Juei War, but he succeeded the territory in Nose-gun, Settsu Province, which his father had developed, served as a central government official (lower or middle ranked), such as Kurodo, Daigaku no suke (Assistant Director of the Bureau of Education) and Bungp no kuni no kami (Governor of Bungo Province), and reached Shogoinoge (Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) in the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 能勢氏の先祖にあたる人物であるが、鎌倉幕府の御家人となっていたかは不明で、承久の乱の際の動向も不明である。
sen.e: He is the ancestor of the Nose clan, but it is unknown if he was a Gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods) of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and what he has done during Jokyu War is also unknown.

He is the ancestor of the Nose clan, but it is unknown if he was a Gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods) of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and what he has done during Jokyu War is also unknown.

He is the ancestor of the Nose clan, but it is unknown if he was a Gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods) of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and what he has done during Jokyu War is also unknown.

sen.j: 多くの子女があり、息子たちも中央の官人として土御門院蔵人などを務めたとされる。
sen.e: It is believed that he had many daughters, and that his sons served as a central government official, such as Tsuchimikado In Kurodo (Chamberlain).
It is believed that he had many daughters, and that his sons served as a central government official, such as Tsuchimikadoin Kurodo (Chamberlain).
It is believed that he had many daughters, and that his sons served as a central government official, such as Tsuchimikadoin Kurodo (Chamberlain).

sen.j: また、『尊卑分脈』の記述によると娘の一人は平信範の室となり信仲なる子を儲けたとされるが、同平氏系図では確認出来ず年代的な整合性においても疑問である（別の一女の夫高階光兼の子に信仲の名がみえる）。
sen.e: According to "Sonpi Bunmyaku" (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the lineages of the aristocracy), one of his daughters became a wife of TAIRA no Nobunori and bore a son named Nobunaka, but it can not be confirmed in a family tree of the Taira clan, and it is doubtful in terms of the chronological consistency (it is described that another daughter who married with Mitsukane TAKASHINA bore a son named Nobunaka).

According to "Sonpi Bunmyaku" (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the lineages of the aristocracy), one of his daughters became a wife of TAIRA no Nobunori and bore a son named Nobunaka, but it can not be confirmed in a family tree of the Taira clan, and it is doubtful in terms of the chronological consistency (it is described that another daughter who married with Mitsukane TAKASHINA bore a son named Nobunaka).
